guideline.name: Annotation of CPIC Guideline for fosphenytoin, phenytoin and CYP2C9, HLA-B

relatedGenes.name: cytochrome P450 family 2 subfamily C member 9
major histocompatibility complex, class I, B

text.html: No adjustments needed from typical dosing strategies. Subsequent doses should be adjusted according to therapeutic drug monitoring, response, and side effects. An HLA-B*15:02 negative test does not eliminate the risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN and patients should be carefully monitored according to a usual standard.

No adjustments needed from typical dosing strategies. Subsequent doses should be adjusted according to therapeutic drug monitoring, response, and side effects. An HLA-B*15:02 negative test does not eliminate the risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN and patients should be carefully monitored according to a usual standard.

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298382

text.html: For first dose, use typical initial or loading dose. For subsequent doses, use approximately 25% less than typical maintenance dose. Subsequent doses should be adjusted according to therapeutic drug monitoring, response and side effects. An HLA-B*15:02 negative test does not eliminate the risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN, and patients should be carefully monitored according to a usual standard.

implications: CYP2C9: Reduced phenytoin metabolism; Higher plasma concentrations will increase probability of toxicities.

text.html: No recommendation

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298409

text.html:
If patient is phenytoin-naive, do not use phenytoin/fosphenytoin. Avoid carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine.

Other Considerations

Other aromatic anticonvulsants, including eslicarbazepine, lamotrigine, and phenobarbital, have weaker evidence linking SJS/TEN with the HLA-B*15:02 allele; however, caution should still be used in choosing an alternative agent.

implications: CYP2C9: Reduced phenytoin metabolism; Higher plasma concentrations will increase probability of toxicities.
HLA-B: Increased risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298369

text.html:
If patient is phenytoin-naive, do not use phenytoin/fosphenytoin. Avoid carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine.

Other Considerations

Other aromatic anticonvulsants, including eslicarbazepine, lamotrigine, and phenobarbital, have weaker evidence linking SJS/TEN with the HLA-B*15:02 allele; however, caution should still be used in choosing an alternative agent.

implications: CYP2C9: Reduced phenytoin metabolism; Higher plasma concentrations will increase probability of toxicities.
HLA-B: Increased risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298431

text.html:
If the patient has previously used phenytoin continuously for longer than three months without incidence of cutaneous adverse reactions, cautiously consider use of phenytoin in the future. The latency period for drug-induced SJS/TEN is short with continuous dosing and adherence to therapy (4-28 days), and cases usually occur within three months of dosing.

Other Considerations

Previous tolerance of phenytoin is not indicative of tolerance to other aromatic anticonvulsants.

implications: CYP2C9: Reduced phenytoin metabolism; Higher plasma concentrations will increase probability of toxicities.
HLA-B: Increased risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN

If the patient has previously used phenytoin continuously for longer than three months without incidence of cutaneous adverse reactions, cautiously consider use of phenytoin in the future. The latency period for drug-induced SJS/TEN is short with continuous dosing and adherence to therapy (4-28 days), and cases usually occur within three months of dosing.

Other Considerations

Previous tolerance of phenytoin is not indicative of tolerance to other aromatic anticonvulsants.

implications: CYP2C9: Reduced phenytoin metabolism; Higher plasma concentrations will increase probability of toxicities.
HLA-B: Increased risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298363

text.html: For first dose, use typical initial or loading dose. For subsequent doses use approximately 50% less than typical maintenance dose. Subsequent doses should be adjusted according to therapeutic drug monitoring, response, and side effects. An HLA-B*15:02 negative test does not eliminate the risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN, and patients should be carefully monitored according to a usual standard.

implications: CYP2C9: Reduced phenytoin metabolism; Higher plasma concentrations will increase probability of toxicities.

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298429

text.html:
If the patient has previously used phenytoin continuously for longer than three months without incidence of cutaneous adverse reactions, cautiously consider use of phenytoin in the future. The latency period for drug-induced SJS/TEN is short with continuous dosing and adherence to therapy (4-28 days), and cases usually occur within three months of dosing.

Other Considerations

Previous tolerance of phenytoin is not indicative of tolerance to other aromatic anticonvulsants.

implications: HLA-B: Increased risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN

text.html: No recommendation

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298389

text.html:
If the patient has previously used phenytoin continuously for longer than three months without incidence of cutaneous adverse reactions, cautiously consider use of phenytoin in the future. The latency period for drug-induced SJS/TEN is short with continuous dosing and adherence to therapy (4-28 days), and cases usually occur within three months of dosing.

Other Considerations

Previous tolerance of phenytoin is not indicative of tolerance to other aromatic anticonvulsants.

implications: CYP2C9: Reduced phenytoin metabolism; Higher plasma concentrations will increase probability of toxicities.
HLA-B: Increased risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298407

text.html:
If patient is phenytoin-naive, do not use phenytoin/fosphenytoin. Avoid carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine.

Other Considerations

Other aromatic anticonvulsants, including eslicarbazepine, lamotrigine, and phenobarbital, have weaker evidence linking SJS/TEN with the HLA-B*15:02 allele; however, caution should still be used in choosing an alternative agent.

implications: HLA-B: Increased risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298412

text.html:
If patient is phenytoin-naive, do not use phenytoin/fosphenytoin. Avoid carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine.

Other Considerations

Other aromatic anticonvulsants, including eslicarbazepine, lamotrigine, and phenobarbital, have weaker evidence linking SJS/TEN with the HLA-B*15:02 allele; however, caution should still be used in choosing an alternative agent.

implications: HLA-B: Increased risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166298372

text.html: No adjustments needed from typical dosing strategies. Subsequent doses should be adjusted according to therapeutic drug monitoring, response and side effects. An HLA-B*15:02 negative test does not eliminate the risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN and patients should be carefully monitored according to a usual standard.

implications: CYP2C9: Slightly reduced phenytoin metabolism; however, this does not appear to translate into increased side effects.

Subsequent doses should be adjusted according to therapeutic drug monitoring, response, and side effects. An HLA-B*15:02 negative test does not eliminate the risk of phenytoin-induced SJS/TEN, and patients should be carefully monitored according to a usual standard.
